intro: Roupala peruviana, commonly known as the Andean walnut, is a deciduous tree native to the Andes mountains of South America. It belongs to the family Proteaceae and is characterized by its compound leaves and showy, yellowish-green flowers. The tree produces small, edible fruits that contain a single seed, which is encased in a hard, woody shell. It thrives in temperate to subtropical climates and is often found in moist, well-drained soils. Due to its ornamental value and potential for sustainable use, it is of interest in both horticulture and ecological restoration.
